WRITING.TITLE: Which one of you did it!?
WRITING.TEXT:
Well I got my friend playing Dark Souls 3. Let's call him Dirty Harry. It is Harry's first ever Souls game and he went in dry and lonely. Let me preface this by saying he knows nothing about the games, especially about any deeper mechanics such as the one he had the (un)fortunate pleasure of slapping him in the face.
So Harry made it to the High Wall of Lothric. Nice job Harry, it only took you about 4 hours. Upon his exploration Harry struggles against fire breathing monsters and multiple pathways, he really just needs some friendly guidance in his dark journey because it's all too much for Dirty Harry. And then, an angel in a knight's clothing and a purple name. A friend!? Harry's new helper helps clear out those tough mobs and reveals hidden secrets and items. Just when Harry thought there was nothing but frustrations and violence this angel has showed companionship and guidance in this dark world.
And that's when these two travelers happen upon a chest. A chest all by itself. The angel points towards it and Harry doesn't think twice. Only when the mimic's jaws fastened down on Dirty Harry did he fully start to understand the world he is a part of. Maybe one day he can look back at this and appreciate just how special a moment he experienced, but until then, I hope whoever did this to him recorded it.
"Dude this fucking NPC set me up" - Dirty Harry

WRITING.TITLE: My first impression of the Chapayev
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm typing this on my phone (slow work day) so please excuse any typos or poor formatting.
So this ship is a bit of a mixed bag. I have over 100 games played in the Mikhail Kutuzov and even though the ships may seem similar, they require a pretty different playstyle in a lot of ways. For starters, the maneuverability on the Chapayev is abysmal (7.7 second rudder shift: 890m radius) and it's one of the main things keeping the ship from being a powerhouse. This radically changes how well the ship can perform fighting vs BBs and dodging torps as the turning radius exceeds most BBs. The Chapayev is unforgiving in this regard, especially when compared to the very agile Kutuzov. Combined with the large citadel, low HP pool, and paper thin armor, I am much less confident in my ability to tango vs BBs than I was in the Kutuzov with smoke screens. Mistakes are easy to make and get punished very hard. Instagib style.
However, things aren't all bad. I run concealment expert on the Chapayev (which is a must have for every cruiser, imo) and this drops the detection down to 10.2km which is a big help. Huge, even. Not only does this give you a nice safety net to disappear when things start getting froggy and/or you need to reposition, this ship gets the most useful stealth firing capability of all the T8 cruisers so far. Being able to shoot from 14.2km without being seen is actually starting to get close enough to ideal. For most other cruisers, the range is either too far or too narrow a margin to be reliable. While 14.2km is still not close enough for your firepower to be entirely efficient, the option is there for your use. That said stealth firing itself is not a mechanic you can rely on as more often than not there's going to be something to spot you like planes or a DD. Having 10.2km concealment also synergies well with another strength of the ship: radar.
The new Radar ability is DEVASTATING to enemy DDs when you give it a little bit of teamwork. By yourself, you probably can't kill the DD in the short 20 seconds it is active as you will realistically get only 2 salvos before it ends. I play in divisions very frequently however, and if we get another cruiser or DD (or both) ready for the ability to activate, that DD is good as dead more times than not. And even if the DD manages to survive, they will have escaped very banged up and with your whole team knowing their last known location. Most importantly the CV. I know that most DDs aren't actively playing around this ability yet, so I'm not going to jump on the "it's completely broken" bandwagon yet, but the ability is as strong as it is situational. It can easily be wasted and the cooldown is very long. The ability extends past your detection range, so if you're detected by something, you know you can use radar to find them.
AA is super strong. Not the strongest, but still good enough to rekt.
At the risk of being too long winded, I'll leave it at that. My overall impression is that this ship is incredibly strong with proper teamwork, but its poor maneuverability keeps the ship from being independently difficult to deal with. Mistakes get punished without mercy. For this reason, I imagine it'll be a difficult ship for a lot of people to play without divs in randoms.

How good has Wargaming been in the past about game balancing?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi all! I've just recently gotten into the game of boats and I'm loving it way more than I thought I would. I was hooked after just one match and my friends and I are eagerly awaiting clan battles. But one thing concerns me, balance. I've been in the situation before where the developers just seem to not understand how their game is played so they make the wrong changes or simply never change anything. And having played this game of boats a little bit now and seeing the recent discussion on this subreddit, there are definitely areas that deserve some assessment.
*See title of post*
Since I didn't play WoT, I figured I'd ask (this is my first Wargaming game). As far as I'm aware, that game sill has a thriving competitive scene, yeah? That's gotta be a good sign.
